Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia and Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Rickettsial diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain spotted fever)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems including the joints (arthropathy, synovitis) and the heart (acute pericarditis), can cause fever, and CNS lupus can lead to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for causing chronic arthropathy and synovitis, it can also lead to systemic complications such as fever, pericarditis, and in severe cases, systemic involvement can contribute to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Can lead to fever, acute pericarditis, and arthropathy. Embolic phenomena can cause a wide range of symptoms including delirium from cerebral emboli.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A systemic granulomatous disease that can affect any organ system, causing fever, arthralgia (or arthropathy in chronic cases), acute pericarditis, and neurosarcoidosis can lead to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Common viruses, often Coxsackie, can cause acute pericarditis and may have systemic symptoms including fever. Joint symptoms are less common but can be present in terms of arthralgia.

diagnoses.name: Adult-onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by high fevers, arthritis, and a salmon-colored bumpy rash. Can also lead to pericarditis and systemic inflammation, potentially contributing to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body (cross-reactivity). Common symptoms include arthritis, conjunctivitis, urethritis, fever, and in severe cases, complications can include pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi transmitted via tick bites. Can cause arthritis, particularly knee synovitis, fever, and in late stages, neurological manifestations (including delirium) and carditis, which may manifest as pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: A systemic infectious disease that can cause fever, weight loss, and night sweats. Extrapulmonary TB can present with pericarditis and arthritis. Tuberculous meningitis can lead to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Septic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Infection of a joint can cause fever, severe joint pain (arthropathy), and inflammation (synovitis). In severe or disseminated infections, patients may experience delirium, especially if there is concurrent bacteremia leading to acute pericarditis.

diagnoses: Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B and C)
Lupus Nephritis as part of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
Vasculitis (e.g., Microscopic Polyangiitis, Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, in the absence of other physical symptoms)
Scurvy – marked by Vitamin C deficiency, could explain the follicular hyperkeratosis, arthropathy, thrombocytopenia, and neuropsychiatric disorders such as psychosis.
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) – a chronic autoimmune disease that can feature arthropathy, thrombocytopenia, psychosis, and skin manifestations that might resemble follicular hyperkeratosis.
Pellagra – caused by niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency, leading to dermatitis similar to follicular hyperkeratosis, diarrhea, dementia (which could present as delirium and psychosis).

Porphyria – a group of disorders that can involve skin manifestations similar to follicular hyperkeratosis, neuro-psychiatric symptoms such as psychosis or delirium, and thrombocytopenia in some types.

HIV/AIDS – this viral infection can lead to a wide array of symptoms including follicular hyperkeratosis, thrombocytopenia, various neuropsychiatric disorders, and increased risk of arthritic syndromes.
Schizophrenia – primarily related to the psychosis symptom, but chronic cases can lead to neglect of personal nutrition or hygiene, indirectly causing symptoms like follicular hyperkeratosis.
Hepatic Encephalopathy – associated with liver dysfunction, leading to delirium or psychosis. Other liver-related issues might cause arthropathy and thrombocytopenia.
Vitamin B12 Deficiency – can cause neurological symptoms (delirium, psychosis), and hematological symptoms like thrombocytopenia. Skin manifestations may resemble hyperkeratosis.
Zinc Deficiency – could lead to follicular hyperkeratosis, may also impact mental health causing psychosis, and has been associated with arthritic symptoms.
Alcoholism – chronic alcohol misuse can lead to a variety of deficiencies and direct neurotoxic effects resulting in psychosis or delirium, thrombocytopenia, and other symptoms.
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Epstein-Barr virus, COVID-19)
Tick-borne diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.rationale: GERD can lead to laryngitis, dysgeusia (altered taste), and dyspnea without affecting pulmonary function tests directly. It may also contribute to electrolyte imbalances due to chronic esophagitis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome can present with a wide range of symptoms including attention deficit and dyspnea. Electrolyte abnormalities might be secondary to reduced intake or altered metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Anxiety can manifest with attention deficit, dyspnea (especially in the form of hyperventilation syndrome), and dysgeusia. Anxiety stress responses can also lead to abnormal electrolyte levels.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Sjögren's Syndrome, an autoimmune disorder, can cause dysgeusia due to dry mouth and might lead to laryngitis. It has also been associated with various systemic symptoms, including those affecting attention and electrolyte imbalances.

diagnoses.name: COVID-19
diagnoses.rationale: COVID-19 has been associated with a broad spectrum of symptoms, including laryngitis, attention deficit, dysgeusia, and dyspnea. It can also cause abnormal electrolyte levels.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic Kidney Disease can lead to abnormal electrolyte levels and dyspnea due to fluid overload. It might also be associated with dysgeusia due to uremia and attention deficits due to the overall impact on health.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Diabetes can cause abnormal electrolytes, especially when glucose levels are poorly controlled. It may also contribute to attention deficits and possibly dysgeusia through its effects on nerves (diabetic neuropathy).

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Hypothyroidism can cause dyspnea, attention deficits, and abnormal electrolyte levels due to its systemic effects on metabolism. It might also indirectly contribute to laryngitis and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.rationale: Iron deficiency anemia can cause dyspnea and may affect attention. It could also potentially lead to dysgeusia and contribute to laryngitis symptoms due to overall weakened immunity.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.rationale: POTS can lead to dyspnea, attention deficit, and may be associated with dysgeusia and abnormal electrolyte levels due to its impact on autonomic nervous system function.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Vitamin Deficiency (e.g., Vitamin C deficiency leading to scurvy, which can affect healing and cause oral pain)
Connective Tissue Diseases (e.g., SLE - Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
Sleep disorders (e.g., insomnia, obstructive sleep apnea)
Nasal dryness or irritation leading to epistaxis
Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal Infections (PANDAS)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition characterized by high levels of glucose in the blood, which might account for the symptom of hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: COVID-19
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which has been associated with dysosmia, coryza, and dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing sneezing, coryza, and often associated with various dermatologic manifestations, including dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism can cause metabolic dysfunctions presenting as hyperglycemia and may contribute to skin changes such as dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes hives and dermatographism without a known cause, which can be exacerbated by infections or other systemic conditions.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which mast cells inappropriately release chemical mediators, leading to a variety of symptoms including dermatographism, dyspnea, and potentially altering taste and smell senses.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A multisystem autoimmune disease that can present with dermatographism, pulmonary symptoms like dyspnea, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A systemic granulomatous disease that can affect the skin, causing lesions that may mimic dermatographism, and lungs, potentially causing dyspnea without abnormal pulmonary function tests.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A vasculitis that can affect various organs, possibly presenting with skin manifestations like dermatographism, and lung involvement leading to dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reactions
diagnoses.description: Certain medications can induce hyperglycemia, dermatological reactions like dermatographism, alter smell and taste perception, and cause respiratory symptoms including dyspnea.

diagnoses: HIV/AIDS (for the increased susceptibility to infection)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Common cause of hyperthyroidism which can sometimes be associated with skin changes and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by telangiectasias which can lead to bleeding and is associated with a variety of systemic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: Connective tissue disease that can cause lymphadenopathy, skin changes, and potentially lead to hyperthyroidism due to thyroid involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Cancer of the lymphatic system causing lymphadenopathy. Can have systemic effects that indirectly affect the thyroid and cause skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.reasoning: A disorder involving mast cells accumulation in the skin and potentially other organs, leading to a variety of symptoms including angioedema and telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Autoimmune disease that can lead to lymphadenopathy and potentially affect the thyroid gland, with possible skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Multi-system inflammatory disease that can cause lymphadenopathy, skin changes including erythema nodosum, and potentially affect the thyroid.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.reasoning: A type of leukemia that can lead to lymphadenopathy and have indirect effects on the thyroid and skin due to systemic illness.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Thyroiditis (Hashimoto's with atypical presentation or silent hyperthyroid phase)
diagnoses.reasoning: Commonly leads to hypothyroidism but can initially present with a hyperthyroid phase (Hashitoxicosis). Autoimmunity could be linked to systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Inflammation of the blood vessels which can cause a wide range of systemic symptoms including skin manifestations (such as telangiectasias), angioedema, and lymphadenopathy.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's disease
Mental disorders due to known physiological conditions
Endocrine disorders, particularly those affecting the adrenal or thyroid glands

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune diseases
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body, which could manifest in various forms, including skin issues (e.g., dyshydrotic eczema), bladder problems (e.g., interstitial cystitis), and blood disorders (e.g., thrombocytosis).

diagnoses.name: Chronic inflammatory diseases
diagnoses.description: Long-term inflammation can lead to multiple symptoms, affecting the skin, bladder, blood, and causing ulcers in the gastrointestinal tract.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic syndrome
diagnoses.description: A cluster of conditions (increased blood pressure, high blood sugar, excess body fat around the waist, and abnormal cholesterol levels) that occur together, increasing your risk of heart disease, stroke, and diabetes, and potentially contributing to conditions like obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the marrow to make too many red blood cells. It can cause thrombocytosis and lead to complications like ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Chronic venous insufficiency
diagnoses.description: Occurs when your leg veins don't allow blood to flow back up to your heart. Symptoms can include ulcers but can also contribute to conditions associated with thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Sleep disordered breathing
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders characterized by abnormal respiratory patterns or insufficient ventilation during sleep, including obstructive sleep apnea, which can have systemic effects impacting multiple organ systems.

diagnoses.name: Essential thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which your body produces too many platelets (thrombocytosis), leading to a risk of thrombosis that can cause complications affecting various organs and systems.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that can cause patches of abnormal skin (which could potentially be confused with dyshydrotic eczema), and has been linked to an increased risk of metabolic syndrome, which in turn can lead to obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal disorders
diagnoses.description: A broad category of diseases that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, including causing ulcers, which can lead to or exacerbate other conditions through mechanisms of chronic pain and stress.

diagnoses.name: Chronic kidney disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys do not work as well as they should. It can lead to a build-up of waste products in the body, which can affect many organs and systems, potentially aggravating conditions such as interstitial cystitis and contributing to the development of thrombocytosis.
Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypoglycemia is a common manifestation, and diabetes can indirectly lead to hypertension and contribute to chronic pain conditions.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypertension and diabetes (suggested by hypoglycemia) are risk factors. Can also contribute to electrolyte imbalances leading to symptoms like angioedema.

diagnoses.description: Oral Lichen Planus
diagnoses.reasoning: Could be misinterpreted as leukoplakia. It's an inflammatory condition that can lead to white patches in the mouth.

diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause elevated blood pressure (hypertension), chronic pain due to myxedema, and hypoglycemia due to slowed metabolism.

diagnoses.description: Lupus
diagnoses.reasoning: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms including oral lesions similar to leukoplakia, hypertension, and kidney dysfunction leading to electrolyte imbalances.

diagnoses.description: Angioedema
diagnoses.reasoning: One of the symptoms presented, which can be idiopathic or associated with other systemic conditions, including reactions to medications commonly used to treat hypertension.

diagnoses.description: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: A condition of excess cortisol that can cause hypertension, back pain from vertebral fractures due to osteoporosis, and glucose intolerance leading to hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.description: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: Though more specific to females, it can cause hypertension and is closely related to insulin resistance, which could lead to hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.description: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to kidney involvement (resulting in hypertension and possibly hypoglycemia due to organ dysfunction), and chronic pain. Oral manifestations may mimic leukoplakia.

diagnoses.description: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.reasoning: A cancer that can cause bone pain (including back pain), kidney damage leading to hypertension, and hypoglycemia. Less directly related to leukoplakia but can cause various oral health issues.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. Patients can also experience systemic symptoms, including skin dryness (xerosis) and neurological manifestations such as seizures.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that destroys the bile ducts in your liver. Symptoms may include pruritus. Neurological complications can lead to behavioral changes.

diagnoses.name: Hepatic Encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A decline in brain function that occurs as a result of severe liver disease. It is characterized by personality changes, intellectual impairment, and a depressed level of consciousness. Pruritus can be an associated symptom due to the buildup of toxins.

diagnoses.name: Neurodermatitis
diagnoses.description: A skin condition that starts with an itchy patch of skin that becomes thicker and leathery from scratching. It can be associated with stress and anxiety, which may lead to obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. It can cause xerosis and in some cases, seizures. Persistent hyperglycemia can lead to complications that manifest with various symptoms including migratory pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system. It can cause seizures in advanced stages due to central nervous system involvement and pruritus is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Common symptoms include dry skin (xerosis) and muscle cramps, which can be associated with seizure-like activity. Some patients may experience depression that can manifest as obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including neurological symptoms that can appear as seizure disorders and psychiatric symptoms such as obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by systemic inflammation that affects multiple organs. Symptoms can include dry eyes (sicca syndrome) and skin manifestations like xerosis. Neurological involvement can lead to seizures.

diagnoses.name: Renal Failure
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the kidneys lose the ability to remove waste and balance fluids. It can lead to xerosis due to uremic toxins affecting the skin. Pruritus is a common complaint, and neurological complications can include seizures.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is a type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can lead to an increased number of white blood cells, including basophils, causing bone pain and may have effects on the gastrointestinal system, potentially contributing to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder wherein mast cells are abnormally accumulated in multiple organs, including the bone marrow. This condition can result in basophilia, bone pain, and various gastrointestinal issues, including malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare bone marrow cancer that disrupts the body's normal production of blood cells, resulting in bone pain, abnormalities in blood cell counts including basophilia, and potentially impacting the body's ability to absorb nutrients, leading to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland is underactive and doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. It can lead to various symptoms including fatigue, weight gain, menstrual irregularities such as dysmenorrhea, and myxedema which can affect gastrointestinal function, leading to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A painful disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus — the endometrium — grows outside your uterus. It can cause severe dysmenorrhea and is associated with chronic inflammation, which may indirectly contribute to some of the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing malabsorption, and may also lead to bone pain due to malnutrition. While not directly related to basophilia or Kounis syndrome, its systemic impact can influence various bodily systems.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)
diagnoses.description: A type of tumor that occurs in the digestive tract. It could cause malabsorption and potentially lead to systemic symptoms like basophilia due to its effects on the immune system. Pain from tumor growth can mimic bone pain if it affects nearby structures or metastasizes to bone.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder that leads to the overproduction of red blood cells. It can also result in elevated white blood cells, including basophils, and can cause bone pain. Though it mainly affects red blood cells, the overproduction of blood cells can create issues with blood viscosity and circulation impacting various symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can cause some of the vertebrae in your spine to fuse together. This disease causes chronic pain and is associated with inflammation that could conceivably lead to systemic symptoms like basophilia. It's noted for causing significant pain, including bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that affects the lining of the digestive tract. Crohn's disease can cause malabsorption and is associated with extraintestinal symptoms such as bone pain, and in some cases, may lead to menstrual irregularities including dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses: Secondary immunodeficiency (due to external cause such as medication)

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It may lead to symptoms like headaches and sensory neuropathies. Hypermobility is often seen in patients with fibromyalgia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It can cause symptoms like sensory neuropathies and headaches. Other related symptoms might include issues with motor control and temperature regulation.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes are a group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Hypermobility is a common symptom. While not directly causing vaginitis or hypothermia, the related complications could lead to a broad range of secondary symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Sjögren's Syndrome is an autoimmune disease that affects the glands that produce tears and saliva. It can also cause peripheral neuropathy, leading to sensory loss. Headaches and broader systemic symptoms could be secondary effects.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is a systemic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body. Symptoms can include headaches, vague neurological complaints, and temperature regulation issues.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme Disease is an infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms, including sensory neuropathies and headaches. Hypothermia is not a direct symptom but could relate to broader systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes Mellitus can lead to a form of nerve damage known as diabetic neuropathy, causing sensory impairments. While headaches, hypothermia, and hypermobility are not classic symptoms, diabetic complications could broadly affect health in various ways.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that affects the lining of the joints, causing painful swelling. Patients can have systemic symptoms, including sensory neuropathies. Secondary Sjögren’s Syndrome can occur with RA, potentially linking to headaches.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism, or underactive thyroid gland, can lead to symptoms including hypothermia (temperature regulation issues) and can influence the occurrence of headaches. Peripheral neuropathy is also a potential complication.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are its first symptoms. It can lead to sensory neuropathies but is less likely to be directly associated with headaches, hypothermia, or hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Upper respiratory tract infection
diagnoses.description: A common viral infection that affects the nose, throat, and airways.

diagnoses.name: Acute sinusitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the sinuses that typically occurs after a cold or an allergic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic sinusitis
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the prolonged inflammation of the sinuses, often accompanied by infection, and lasting for more than 12 weeks.

diagnoses.name: Allergic rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction that causes sneezing, congestion, and itchy, watery eyes.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where stomach acid comes up from the stomach into the esophagus, possibly affecting the throat and causing symptoms allied to laryngitis and sinusitis.

diagnoses.name: Sleep apnea
diagnoses.description: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing or periods of shallow breathing during sleep. It can lead to non-restorative sleep.

diagnoses.name: Generalized anxiety disorder
diagnoses.description: An anxiety disorder characterized by excessive, uncontrollable worry about everyday things.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. It can exacerbate or contribute to symptoms like non-restorative sleep and anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Viral pharyngitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the pharynx caused by a viral infection, leading to a sore throat and possibly affecting the ears and sinuses.

diagnoses.name: Acute bronchitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the bronchial tubes, which carry air to and from the lungs. It's usually caused by a viral infection.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of adrenal gland tissue. It results in the release of too much epinephrine and norepinephrine, hormones that control heart rate, metabolism, and blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Caused by a carcinoid tumor that secretes serotonin or other chemicals into the bloodstream. Symptoms include flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin and other tissues, leading to flushing, nausea, and episodes of low blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: The overproduction of a hormone by the thyroid gland, causing the body's metabolism to increase, leading to symptoms including sweating, weight loss, and difficulty focusing.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a very low level of blood glucose (sugar), leading to symptoms such as sweating, weakness, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN1)
diagnoses.description: A rare hereditary syndrome causing tumors in endocrine glands leading to overproduction of hormones, causing a variety of symptoms including weakness and sweating.

diagnoses.name: Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors (PNETs)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the pancreas and can lead to symptoms such as nausea, weakness, sweating, and diarrhea from hormone overproduction.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear, which can lead to physical symptoms such as sweating, palpitations, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder
diagnoses.description: A condition where patients experience neurological symptoms, such as weakness, without a clear structural neurological cause.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Dysreflexia
diagnoses.description: A condition where there is an abnormal overreaction of the autonomic nervous system to stimulation, leading to symptoms like episodic hypertension, flushing, and sweating.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to symptoms such as angioedema, conjunctival injection, and gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting that may be associated with gastrointestinal symptoms, but less commonly with conjunctival injections or angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Toxic shock syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections, characterized by fever, rash, hypotension, diarrhea, and potentially multi-organ involvement.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that causes episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), which could be accompanied by gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Drug reactions
diagnoses.description: Adverse drug reactions can manifest as angioedema, skin rashes, gastrointestinal symptoms, or even anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.name: Viral infections
diagnoses.description: Certain viral infections can cause a constellation of symptoms including diarrhea, rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, and sometimes more systemic features.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis
diagnoses.description: A rare, severe disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, often medication-induced, can present with conjunctival injections, angioedema, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Acute gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract that can cause diarrhea and may accompany symptoms like conjunctival injection due to dehydration.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can present with a wide range of symptoms, including those listed, though not typically as a primary presentation.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection characterized by a sore throat, fever, and a characteristic rash, with potential for associated symptoms listed.

diagnoses: Toxic reaction to insect sting or bite
Drug reaction (with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms)
Viral or bacterial infections causing hives and GI upset
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Allergic reaction (to food, insect stings, medications)
Anaphylaxis (if severe and sudden with skin reactions)
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation triggered by an allergic reaction
Viral respiratory infection complicated by an allergic reaction
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by neurological phenomena (aura) that precedes the headache.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the cranial nerve that connects the inner ear to the brain.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose).

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia burgdorferi bacterium, transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged ticks.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy
diagnoses.description: A rare, degenerative neurological disorder affecting your body's involuntary functions, including blood pressure, breathing, bladder function, and motor control.

diagnoses.name: Neurosyphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection of the brain or spinal cord. It usually occurs in persons who have had untreated syphilis for many years.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to anemia, causing you to feel tired and weak. Severe deficiency can result in nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe throbbing and pulsating pain on one side of the head. The aura phase includes symptoms such as phonophobia, visual disturbances, and sometimes speech disturbances like aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted, causing brain tissue to be deprived of oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms may include sudden weakness, vertigo, difficulty speaking, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those observed in a stroke. It can include speech difficulties, weakness, dizziness, and other symptoms, but usually resolves within a few minutes to hours without lasting effects.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). Symptoms can include fatigue, difficulty walking, numbness or weakness, vertigo, and problems with speech.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, Meniere's disease affects only one ear and can also cause tinnitus and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can be cancerous (malignant) or non-cancerous (benign). Depending on their location, they can cause a variety of symptoms including weakness, difficulties with speech, and balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, leading to periods of unusual behavior, sensations and sometimes loss of awareness. Specific forms of epilepsy may present with vertigo, phonophobia, and other sensory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuritis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the vestibular nerve, commonly caused by a viral infection. It results in severe vertigo, dizziness, and difficulties with balance but does not typically affect hearing.

diagnoses.name: Basilar Migraine
diagnoses.description: A form of migraine that is believed to involve the brainstem or the basilar artery in the brain. Symptoms prior to the headache phase can include vertigo, tinnitus, temporary blindness, aphasia, and ataxia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: An abscess caused by an infection in the brain. Symptoms can mimic many other conditions, including causing weaknesses, speech problems, headaches, and can include fever and neck stiffness.

diagnoses: Primary angiitis of the central nervous system

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances and other sensory changes.

diagnoses.name: Stroke (Cerebrovascular Accident)
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it's caused by a temporary disruption in the blood supply to part of the brain.

diagnoses.name: Glioma (Brain Tumor)
diagnoses.description: A type of tumor that occurs in the brain and spinal cord. Gliomas begin in the glial cells that surround nerve cells and help them function.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) where the immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. It can be life-threatening and requires immediate medical attention.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in response to an infection or trauma. It can cause a variety of neurological deficits depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, called arteries, in and around the scalp. It can cause headaches, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, vision problems, and even permanent vision loss.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma)
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor that develops on the vestibulocochlear nerve leading from your inner ear to your brain.

diagnoses.name: Herpes Simplex Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: A rare neurological disorder characterized by inflammation of the brain (encephalitis), caused by the herpes simplex virus.

diagnoses: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) with neurological complications
Poisoning (e.g., Heavy Metal Poisoning, Drug Overdose)
Primary Angiitis of the Central Nervous System
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body including skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, causing a wide range of symptoms including nonscarring alopecia, pericarditis, leukopenia, and can overlap with lichen planus features.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash, which can be associated with systemic manifestations such as pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic issues such as pericarditis and leukopenia. Though less common, skin involvement can mimic lichen planus.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planopilaris
diagnoses.description: A specific type of lichen planus affecting the scalp, leading to a type of nonscarring alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, most commonly the lungs and lymph glands. Skin manifestations can include lichen planus-like eruptions, and it can cause systemic issues like pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease with features of three other diseases: lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It includes symptoms like leukopenia, and nonscarring alopecia, and can involve pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that affects the skin and mucous membranes, which can sometimes be associated with other systemic symptoms or conditions such as leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It is associated with extraglandular manifestations, including skin disorders similar to lichen planus, leukopenia, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, including various skin manifestations that may resemble lichen planus, along with potential heart involvement like pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Discoid Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition of sores with inflammation and scarring favoring the face, ears, and scalp and potentially causing nonscarring alopecia. Systemic lupus erythematosus can also cause symptoms like leukopenia and pericarditis.

diagnoses: Cancer (various types, depending on the context and patient history)
Drug-induced lupus or other drug-related conditions

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and lead to a variety of symptoms, including pleural effusion, nonscarring alopecia, and skin rash. Neurological involvement can result in delirium.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash, could potentially present with features like maculopapular rash and nonscarring alopecia. Systemic involvement might lead to pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Vasculitis
diagnoses.details: Part of the spectrum of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, vasculitis can cause a wide range of symptoms including rash, alopecia, and involvement of internal organs resulting in pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.details: A disease that may present with features similar to SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis including pulmonary involvement (pleural effusion), skin rashes, and hair loss.

diagnoses.name: Hypocomplementemic Urticarial Vasculitis
diagnoses.details: Characterized by urticarial lesions that may appear as a maculopapular rash and can be associated with systemic symptoms, including pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.details: Primarily affects joints but can have systemic manifestations including skin rashes and pulmonary involvement such as pleural effusion. Rarely, it can cause follicular disorders leading to alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs. Skin involvement may present as a rash and, less commonly, alopecia. Neurosarcoidosis can cause delirium, and lung involvement may lead to pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.details: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can lead to symptoms like maculopapular rash (especially after administration of certain antibiotics), and systemic symptoms that might cause pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A severe hypersensitivity reaction to drugs, characterized by rash, hematologic abnormalities, lymphadenopathy, and involvement of internal organs including the lungs (potentially leading to pleural effusion).

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.details: Certain types of lymphoma can present with systemic symptoms including pleural effusion, skin rash, and delirium due to metabolic disturbances or direct neurological involvement.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Kidney Disease related to Hypertension or Diabetes
Schizophrenia (for the psychosis component, if not directly related to a systemic disease)
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) secondary to glomerulonephritis
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
